text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
--Pope John Paul II will pay a two-day visit to Lebanon in May.
--Fourteen Lebanese policemen and three civilians were injured in scuffles when stone-throwing squatters tried to stop workers blasting a tunnel in Beirut.
--Lebanon's weekly treasury bill issue of January 23 raised 467.9 billion Lebanese pounds.
--The Industry and Oil Ministry decreased prices of petrol by 20 Lebanese pounds for each one litre, and 25 pounds for each one litre of gas oil.
--Heavy Israeli shelling on suspected pro-Iranian Hizbollah (Party of God) positions in south Lebanon.
--Israeli official said that Iran has rearmed Hizbollah after the 17-day Israeli blitz against the group in April.
--Prime Minister Hariri visited Damascus on Monday and discussed regional issues with top Syrian officials.
--The cabinet will hold its weekly meeting today and will discuss decreasing taxes on imported new cars.
--General Labour Confederation warns the government not to impose new tax rises.
